Dear Mr. Williams:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
1/19/2023. An exit conference was held with the agency onsite on 1/24/2023. Due to the
violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of
any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the MISEP and your contract. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of
the following information:
(d) Dates and places of contacts, names of persons
interviewed, and names of the interviewers. If children are
interviewed, their last names shall not be included in the
report.
One of six special evaluations reviewed did not show
documentation of the place of all interviews, nor were all
interviews documented in the methodology section of the
evaluation.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the
child in a foster home, then both of the following shall be
documented before a change in placement:
(a) A summary of the services provided during care
up to the time of the change in placement and the needs
that remain to be met.
(b) Provision for any continuing services.
Two of five closed foster child records reviewed did not
show documentation of (a) and (b) as required by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as
follows, unless a greater frequency is medically
indicated:
(ii) For a child 2 years of age or older, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 12
months before placement or a new physical examination

shall be completed within 30 calendar days after
placement.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed showed
the child's medical, due by 4/9/2022, was completed late
on 7/14/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Updated service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each
child and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Five of 18 updated service plans (USP) reviewed
(a)
Two of nine initial service plans reviewed were late by
three and five days respectively.
Repeat Violation- Interim February 2022.
(b):
Five of 15 updated service plans (USP) reviewed (related
to five of eight open foster child records and one of three
open independent living youth records) showed the
respective USP was late by:
• One day
• Two days.
• Four days.
• Nine days.
• Nine days.
Repeat Violation-Interim February 2022; Renewal
December 2020.
CPA Rule 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(a), shall include all of the following
information:
(c) Assessment of the placement selection criteria as
required under R 400.12404 (4).
One of nine initial service plans reviewed (related to
review of eight open foster child records, and three open

independent living youth records) did not show
documentation of (c), as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation-Interim-February 2022.
CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time.
An agency shall have a poly regarding visitation and
parenting time that contains, at a minimum, all of the
following:
(a) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster
child and foster parent in the foster parent’s home at least
once every month.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed did not
show documentation of a July 2022 foster home visit with
the foster child and foster parent.
CPA Rule 400.12607 Agency recommendation.
(4) An agency shall provide the applicants for adoption
with a signed and dated copy of the evaluation and
recommendation upon its completion.
One of nine adoptive family records reviewed did not
show compliance, as required by the rule.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance will all additional MISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 4.22 MiSACWIS (Commitment 22).
DHHS will maintain an operational statewide
automated child welfare information system
(“MiSACWIS”) which will be the primary tracking
system and satisfy federal reporting requirements.
Various open and closed foster child and independent
living youth records, and adoption records reviewed did
not show consistent MISACWIS uploads of all required
documents (i.e., signed service plans, parent agency
treatment plan agreements, DHS-1105, DHS-69s,
medical passport proof of program statement or policies
and procedures and or other documents), at the time of
review. Proof of various documents were provided prior
t o exit.

6.19 5(c) Assessments and Service Plans, Content
(Commitment 69).
Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the
caseworker's supervisor, the parent(s}, and the
child(ren), if of age to participate. If the parent(s) or
child(ren) or both are not available or decline to sign the
plan, the service plan shall include an explanation of the
steps taken to involve them and shall identify any
follow-up actions to be taken to secure their
participation in services.
Two of nine initial service plans and one of 15 updated
service plans reviewed did not show documentation of
the birth parent’s signature.
Repeat Violation-Interim-February 2022; Renewal-
D ecember 2020 cited under FOM-722-8C.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MDHHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional MDHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in

requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-6 Family team meeting.
FTMs should include child welfare staff, parents,
caretakers, foster parents, children, youth, and may also
include extended family, friends, neighbors, community-
based service providers, community representatives,
tribal representatives, for Indian children, or other
professionals involved with the family.
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS using
the FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate forms must
be completed for each type of meeting

Certain circumstances, events, and/or stages of case
progression mandate FTMs must occur within the
required time frames as out lined in the following table.

Agreement and Signature:

The caseworker must obtain signatures from all

FOM 722-8E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary.
The caseworker must complete the DHS-69, Foster
Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary, and upload to
MiSACWIS within the timeframe required for the

• Within three business days of foster care or

Three of three closed independent living youth records
reviewed; and two of eight open foster child records
reviewed (related to the respective child’s replacement)
did not show compliance as required by the standard.
Repeat Violation- Interim- February 2022.

FOM- 801-C Medical passport.
Initial Medical Passport:
For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the
child's placement date to the following:
• Foster care provider.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed did not
show compliance:
• The record did not show documentation that the
respective caregiver for the child’s 7/12/2022,
and 9/27/2022 placement were provided the
child’s medical passport.
• The record did not show documentation the
caregiver for the child’s 11/11/2022 placement
was provided the child’s medical passport. The
agency provided documentation showing it was
provided the caregiver on 1/3/2023.
Repeat Violation-Interim- February 2022; Renewal-
December 2020.
FOM- 802 Mental Health and Behavioral and Developmental
Need of Children under supervision of MDHHS.
All children entering foster care are required to have a
mental health screening within 30 days of removal. The
screening instrument must be completed by a person
who knows the child best, before the child's Early
Periodic, Screening, Diagnostic, and Treatment
(EPSTD)/well child exam.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed did not
show documentation of a mental health screening for
the child, as required by the standard.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R400.12419(1)(h) Initial Service Plan:
The agency was advised that it shall clearly and consistently document the behavior
management plan/action the caregiver is to use with the child, notwithstanding the
age of the child.

V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
R400. 12604 Orientation and application:
Discussion and suggestions occurred with the agency around how to assist adoptive
applicants/ families in retaining information on the adoption process/knowing where
they are in the adoption process.
VI. EVALUATION
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
AND
The agency has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
The first corrective plan related to the agency’s Interim Inspection completed in
February 2022, where the agency received the following rule violations:
• R400.12212(3)(a) Personnel records.
• R400.12312(4) Foster parent training.
• R400.12417(1) (c)-(f) Foster parent information.
• R400.12418(2)(a) & (b) Development of service plans.
• R400.12419(1(c) Initial service plans.
• ISEP 6.19 (5) (c) Assessments & service plans, Content.
• FOM 722-6B Family team meeting.
• FOM 722-8 Case Service Plans-Overview, and Timeframes-Supervisor
Approval.
• FOM 722-8D Treatment Plans- Agreement and Signature.
• FOM 722-8E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary.
• FOM 801-3 Medical passport.
The agency reported experiencing significant worker turnover during the period, which
impacted on some of its efforts to achieve progress with various actions. The agency
provided documentation showing proof of trainings, supervisor/ worker meetings, foster
care and adoption staff meetings, a CPR/First aid tracking tool, memos and email
reminders to staff of service plans and evaluation due dates; FTM and Action summary
PowerPoint tutorials completed for staff; and various quarterly file reviews, all targeted
at education and or discussion with staff; and other efforts to assist and aid staff and the
agency in achievement of its corrective action plan. The agency made some progress,
in that a few rules cited last inspection were not cited this inspection. The agency
received a number of repeat violations, as indicated in this Renewal Inspection report.
The second corrective action plan related to special investigation 2022C0420020
initiated on 5/23/2022. The complaint alleged the agency failed to submit five closed

adoption records to the Department of Health and Human Services (MDHHS) for
permanent retention one year following the final order of the adoptions, as required by
policy. The agency received a citation for R400.12713(5) for Adoption placement
record. The agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan showing all five
records were submitted to MDHHS by 7/19/2022. Dated Acknowledgment Receipt
forms, signed by the department, of the respective child’s closed adoption record’s
submission to the department were provided with the special investigation corrective
action plan. Additionally, the agency indicated it trained its staff on the adoption
placement record rule; and established a monthly plan for submission of finalized
adoption records where finalizations had occurred in the previous 11 months. During
this Renewal Inspection the agency provided proof of adoption record training, and
various Acknowledgment Receipt forms showing submission of closed adoption records
to the department. The agency has completed this corrective plan.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator’s report dated 9/30/2022 was received on 1/3/2023 and
reviewed. The agency assessed its areas of noncompliance indicated in the Interim
Inspection completed in February 2022. The agency completed all aspects as required
by that chief administrator’s document.
Interviews
The chief administrator, licensing director, foster care supervisor/director, adoption
director, and a kinship connection staff person participated in the entrance conference.
The entrance conference centered on a review and discussion of the agency’s last
inspection’s corrective action plan, new staff, the agency’s current challenges if any,
program changes/status/ functioning, and policy changes, if any. The employees
indicated above, and the licensee designee participated in the exit conference. The exit
conference focused on a summary of staff interviews, and the results of the Renewal
Inspection/ indicated rule and policy violations. The Department of Child Welfare
Licensing (DCWL) Analyst also attended the exit conference; and presented her
findings from the unlicensed relatives and foster home visits.
One foster care worker, one dual foster care/adoption worker, two licensing workers,
two independent living workers, one adoption worker, three independent living youths,
and two adoptive families were interviewed during this inspection.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were two safety alerts received this inspection.
Concern:
The DCWL Analyst contacted the unlicensed relative on 11/18/2022, 11/28/2022,
and 12/2/2022 without a return contact from the relative. On 12/6/2022 the DCWL
Analyst contacted the foster care worker and requested the worker to reach out to
the relative and have the relative to contact the DCWL Analyst for a home visit for
the audit. On 12/11//2022 the relative texted the DCWL Analyst indicating she was

not interested in having such a visit and was refusing the audit. The DCWL Analyst
advised the agency to please complete a visit in the unlicensed relative’s home to
verify the safety of the child in the home.
Resolution:
On 12/13/2022 at 3:40 pm, the foster care worker made a home to the unlicensed
relative’s home. The worker had face to face contact with the child and caregiver,
viewed the home, and verified the well-being of the child and home. No concerns
were observed or reported.
Concern:
There was standing water observed in the basement. The foster parent was aware
and is working to rectify the situation. Please verify the situation is repaired.
Resolution:
The agency contacted the foster parent on 11/29/2022 and 11/30/2022. On
11/30/22, the foster parent reported that the Water Department came to her home
and checked the drains, which were all clear and the water had gone down. They
instructed her to contact a plumber for future concerns. Several photos were
provided to the agency on 11/30/22 showing that there is no longer any water in the
foster parent’s basement. The foster parent contacted a plumber and will keep the
agency informed of any updates as it relates to her basement drains/water issue for
the future. The safety concern has been resolved.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
